Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Approaches to Online Implementation and Social Support in Undergraduate Engineering Courses

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: The pandemic of COVID-19 is disrupting undergraduate engineering education globally. Students have been asked to move out of their campus residences and back home to take courses online. While some students may quickly adjust and continue to do well in their courses, others may struggle to feel connected to campus and their courses. Recent research has found that peers are a major support for engineering students and supportive social relationships and networks are critical for navigating through engineering education and careers. This research will provide an understanding of how engineering instructors are supporting student connections in their courses and what other social supports students have during this time. <br/><br/>This research explores how choices made by engineering instructors during the COVID-19 pandemic are associated with undergraduate engineering studentsâ€™ academic social capital and achievement of learning outcomes. This work uses a multiple cross-case comparison of three undergraduate engineering courses taught in different ways. Data is collected from three team-based engineering courses at Purdue University: a large first-year course, a medium-sized senior-level capstone course, and a small service-learning course that has first year through senior-level students. Data collection consists of student surveys, interviews with students, faculty, and graduate teaching assistants, course documents such as syllabi and schedules, and student assignment scores. The findings from this study will make online and in-person instruction more inclusive and easier for instructors because it will help make future decisions to ensure that all students have the resources they need to be successful in the course and to persist in their major. Findings and recommendations will be shared with instructors of the courses studied, potentially influencing the learning experiences of more than 3,000 students each year. The research team will use the results of this research to create a list of best practices for online STEM instructors which will be disseminated to the public through social media, professional organization outlets, and archival journals. Ultimately, findings will inform STEM instructors about what they can do to support the success of all undergraduate students by helping them to build academic social capital, whether during online or in-person instruction.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty-first century technical challenges are complex and require a highly skilled workforce to solve urgent problems. Understanding what helps engineering students succeed academically and persist in their major is important because the US needs more engineering graduates to join the technical workforce. This research explored the ways in which the COVID-19 pandemic affected college students enrolled in engineering in the spring of 2020. 

 

Engineering is a college major that has a reputation for being extremely difficult. Many students who start out in engineering majors leave before graduation. At the same time, social interactions can serve to both develop and support student learning. Students depend on peer interactions such as talking to classmates about topics they do not understand and asking their instructors questions in real-time  to learn important concepts. This study found that the connections engineering students have with instructors and other students are absolutely critical to their academic success and staying in engineering. Many of these relationships suffered when universities across the globe quickly transitioned to teaching online, also called emergency remote teaching. This made it more difficult for students to succeed academically. Students who had been enrolled in engineering for less than a year during the spring 2020 term were more adversely affected than those who were close to graduation because they had fewer close relationships at the university. Engineering students early in their college career relied heavily on their family for encouragement to stay in engineering but did not have peer networks in place on campus to discuss course specific topics. Engineering students who were more established in college, maintained connections with classmates and other peers in their majors. 

 

The study found some strategies instructors can implement to support their students when teaching online (whether planned or unplanned). These strategies can be implemented by instructors in pre-college and college settings and are not specific only to engineering students. The findings also apply to other kinds of disruptions in face-to-face education, such as illness, family emergencies, and extreme weather events. For example, instructors can give team assignments and set up times for students to work together online with explicit team goals of getting to know teammates and sharing contact information with each other. Connecting students with each other serves to support students with peers to reach out to.  When teaching online, instructors can log on to class a few minutes early or stay online after class to ask how students are doing and answer their questions. This helps to replicate the casual interactions that occur in face-to-face classes that are known to support student success. School personnel can encourage students to participate in extracurricular activities and provide virtual office hours. Particularly important when courses are online, instructors and school personnel can provide students access to campus support networks that ultimately serve to encourage students to stick with their education.

 

The research results were shared with thousands of engineering instructors in US and internationally through webinars, educational conferences, and papers in academic journals.
